treasury_media.title: Does wheat make us fat and sick?
treasury_media.description: REVIEW: It has recently been suggested that wheat consumption leads to weight gain due to addiction and overeating. We discuss these arguments and conclude that they cannot be substantiated. Moreover, we conclude that assigning the cause of obesity to one specific type of food or food component, rather than overconsumption and inactive lifestyle in general, is not correct. This review discusses various aspects of wheat and wheat components on health and disease

treasury_media.title: Advances in dietary fibre characterisation. 1. Definition of dietary fibre, physiological relevance, health benefits and analytical aspects | Nutrition Research Reviews | Cambridge Core
treasury_media.description: Basically there are two options for a definition of DF (1) sum the content of NSP, resistant starch and non-digestible oligosaccharides as quantified by distinct methods, (2) use the AOAC method of DF analysis, with additional analyses of non-digestible oligosaccharides  in the food. This review describes the various types of DF, effects of DF consumption on physiology and metabolism, past and current definitions, analytical aspects to measure DF and some aspects of DF claims and food labelling.

It is widely accepted that ASD involves a disorder in brain development. However, the real causes of the neurodevelopmental disorders associated with ASD are not clear. treasury_media.title: Misconceptions about fructose-containing sugars and their role in the obesity epidemic | Nutrition Research Reviews | Cambridge Core
treasury_media.description:
Abstract
A causal role of fructose intake in the aetiology of the global obesity epidemic has been proposed but rests on controversial interpretations of two distinct lines of research. In mechanistic studies, detrimental metabolic effects have been observed after excessive fructose intakes in animals and humans. Increased fructose consumption from added sugars increased  and paralleled the increase in obesity. Yet, a direct causal role of fructose in metabolic diseases is debated
